p: The total phenolic contents in the P. nigrum extracts showed great variation in the leaves (44.75 ± 1.60 to 140.53 ± 14.01 mg GAE·g −1) ( Figure 4A). However, in the fruits we noticed only small changes in the “Cingapura” and “Uthirankota” cultivars ( Figure 4B). According to the literature, these variations can be occasioned by several factors, biotic and abiotic, such as plant defense, senescence, plant development, and interactions with the environment in which they are inserted [ 84].
